titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jefferson Franklin Ray, Jr. Papers

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:54

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The Jefferson Franklin Ray, Jr. Papers consist of correspondence, professional papers, personal papers and photographs that document Ray's private life, family and career. The bulk of the collection chronicles Ray's education at Yale University and professional career as a diplomat and administrator in East Asia from 1920 to 1953. There is also documentation on other family members, including Ray's father, Jefferson Franklin Ray, Sr., who served as a missionary in Japan.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Anne C. Ray, Gerda W. Ray, Jefferson F. Ray, III, Lester A. Ray, and Louis H. Ray, 1991.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jefferson Franklin Ray, Jr. Papers (MS 1607). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jefferson Franklin Ray, Jr. was born in 1905 to Daisy Winston Pettus and Jefferson Franklin Ray, Sr., Baptist missionaries in Kobe, Japan. Ray was raised in Japan, but returned to the United States and attended Vanderbilt University from 1922 to 1923, before transferring to Yale University. He completed his B.A. at Yale in 1926 (Phi Beta Kappa) and studied philosophy and psychology at the Yale University School of Graduate Studies from 1926 to 1929. He worked as an investment counselor in New Haven and New York before becoming the assistant director of the Surplus Division of the Federal Commodities Association in 1934. Ray joined the staff of the New York City Employment and Resources for Emergency Relief Bureau in 1935 and was employed there for the next two years. After four more years working as an investment counselor and with the onset of World War II, Ray served as a special assistant to the American ambassador to China from 1942 to 1945, and as special staff officer to commanding generals in the United States Army in the Chinese, Burmese and Indian theaters from 1941 to 1945. In 1945, Ray became assistant lend-lease administrator and chief of the China division of the Foreign Economic Administration.

From 1945 to 1947, Ray served as director of the Far Eastern office of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) and as acting director of the China office in 1946. He supervised allocations of relief supplies and assistance to China, reorganized and directed the program, and supervised personnel during a period of Chinese social upheaval and tense United Nations policy debate. UNRRA supplies were regularly denied to Communist-controlled areas and diverted to Nationalist-governed regions. Ray and hundreds of other UNRRA employees protested this strategy and sought to deliver relief supplies and support to all Chinese, despite international objections and frequent Chinese Nationalist blockades. Ray published his authorized history, The UNRRA in China, in 1947, detailing UNRRA's ambitions and evaluating its performance. In 1948, the Communist Chinese government awarded Ray the Special Cravat of the Brilliant Star for his humanitarian service as an UNRRA director.

Over the next few years, Ray worked in various advisory and administrative capacities in Korea and other East Asian countries. He was employed by the Department of State, the Committee for the Marshall Plan, the United Nations, the U.S. Educational and Informational Survey Mission to Korea, the United States Far Eastern Commission and the Economic Cooperation Administration's Mission to Korea. Because of his associations with the Institute for Pacific Relations and Alger Hiss, his popularity with Chinese Communists and support for distributing UNRRA supplies to Communist-controlled regions of China, Ray was brought before the Economic Cooperation Administration's Review Board in 1949. Ray was found to be a loyal United States employee, but his reputation was severely damaged. From 1951 to 1953, Ray served as the chief of the Geneva Liaison Office of the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency. After failing to secure government work commensurate with his diplomatic skills and experience, Ray found work in the United States as an investment counselor at Bache & Company, and then as a vice-president of Bayrock, an investment firm, before retiring in 1971

Ray married three times. Ray and Mary Sharretts Haamman were wed in 1934 and divorced in 1945. In 1946, Ray married Hilda Austern, a fellow UNRRA employee, who died in 1971. Later that year, Ray married Martha Henrietta Weinert, who died in 1976. J. Franklin Ray, Jr. died on February 22, 1991, in Santa Fe, New Mexico, where he had just begun a new career teaching Japanese to elementary school students. He was survived by his children: Jefferson F. Ray, III, Louis H. Ray, Lester A. Ray, Gerda W. Ray, and Anne C. Ray

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Jefferson Franklin Ray, Jr. Papers consist of correspondence, professional papers, personal papers and photographs that document Ray's private life, family and career. The bulk of the collection chronicles Ray's education at Yale University and professional career as a diplomat and administrator in East Asia from 1920 to 1953. There is also documentation on other family members, including Ray's father, Jefferson Franklin Ray, Sr., who served as a missionary in Japan.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in four series: I. Correspondence, 1905-1990, n.d. II. Professional Papers, 1933-1973, n.d. III. Personal and Family Papers, 1837-1981, n.d. IV. Photographs, 1879-1961, n.d.

controlaccess.subject: Missionaries -- Japan
controlaccess.corpname: United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence between Ray and his family, friends, and professional associates, arranged alphabetically. The most substantive correspondence relates to Ray's service with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in China and the Economic Cooperation Administration, from 1945 to 1949. Ray's exchanges with fellow administrators and diplomats document UNRRA's efforts to distribute supplies and aid to war-damaged areas of China, where starvation and poverty were rampant and needed supplies were often blocked by Chiang Kai-Shek's American-backed Nationalist government. Correspondence with Colonel Fred D. Harris and UNRRA Director Generals Fiorello LaGuardia, Herbert Lehman and Lowell Rooks documents UNRRA activities in China. Although most of the correspondence between Ray and his second wife, Hilda Austern Ray, is personal, she also worked with the UNRRA in China, so the two frequently discussed the organization's activities.

Ray regularly reviewed Chinese culture and politics with his uncle, William B. Pettus, who headed the California College in China and the Peking Museum. Ray's extensive correspondence with friend Randall Gould, editor of the Shanghai Evening Post, includes thorough, candid discussions of China and UNRRA, and a January 1948 exchange concerns Ray's friendship with Alger Hiss. Correspondence with Mary H. Ray, his first wife, also refers to this friendship. Ray rarely discussed professional matters with family members. Ray's correspondence with his brother Hermon S. Ray primarily concerns his brother's long career as a minister in Hawaii.

did.unittitle: Edgerton, Glen [major-general, director, UNRRA China office]
Eisenhower, Dwight D. [approval of Ray's appointment to UNRRA China office]
Harris, Fred D. [acting chief, UNRRA Far Eastern affairs]
Holland, William. [secretary general, Institute of Pacific Relations]
Kingsley, Donald [agent general, United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency]
Ray, Jefferson Franklin, Sr. [includes letters to/from family members]
Rusk, Dean [brief letters regarding United Nations Secretariat and employment]
Stettinus, E. R. [administrator, Lend-Lease Administration; under-secretary of state]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of professional papers, arranged alphabetically by subject, which primarily document J. Franklin Ray, Jr.'s service in China and Korea from 1942 to 1951. Ray selected UNRRA correspondence of historical value for Jean Herriot's paper, "The UNRRA China Program." These important memos and letters circulated between Ray and other central figures of UNRRA in China. The "Critique" folder contains a draft of an undelivered, angry letter Ray drafted to UNRRA Director General Fiorello LaGuardia, that indicates the extremity of Ray's frustration with the organization, the American government, and the Chinese Nationalists. The remainder of the UNRRA documents includes correspondence, publications, research, notes, press clippings, memos, correspondence, and weekly reports.

"Hearing, Economic Cooperation Administration Review Board" contains legal documents and correspondence from Ray's 1949 hearing, at which Ray successfully defended himself against charges of disloyalty and Communist sympathy. "Employment" contains resumes, recommendations, reports and samples of work. The latter were compiled by Ray to evidence his professional experience prior to 1953 and span the breadth of his career.

"Some Effects of the War on Economic Thought in the USA"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of family records, memorabilia, and Ray's educational materials, arranged alphabetically by subject. Ray's diaries document his personal life and experiences as a Yale undergraduate. Class folders contain class notes, papers, and related materials. Family papers consist of memorabilia and thorough biographical papers documenting the Ray family history. The papers of Jefferson Franklin Ray, Sr. document his life and work as a Baptist missionary in Japan and elsewhere, and include sermons, autobiographical sketches and many writings.

did.unittitle: High school essays and report cards
Biographical [information on Pettus and Ray families]
Yearbooks, Judson College and Jackson High School

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is arranged in three sections: albums, identified images, and unidentified images. "Albums" contains photographs that have been removed from albums created by the Ray family. Though some photographs document missionary activity in Asia, almost all of the photographs from the albums are family snapshots. Identified photographs are arranged by individual and region. Unidentified photographs are arranged by subject. Almost all photographs are black and white, undated, and generally range in size from 2" x 4" to 8" x 10".

did.unittitle: Missionary work [Jefferson Franklin Ray, Sr., Daisy Winston Pettus Ray, et al]
